pullRequest.body:
This PR contains the proof of [Siegel's Lemma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siegel%27s_lemma).
This is a fundamental tool in diophantine approximation and transcendency and says that there exists a "small" integral
non-zero solution of a non-trivial underdetermined system of linear equations with integer coefficients.

theorem `exists_ne_zero_int_vec_norm_le`: Given a non-singular `m × n` matrix `A` with `m < n` the linear
system it determines has a non-zero integer solution `t` with
`‖t‖ ≤ ((n * ‖A‖) ^ ((m : ℝ) / (n - m)))`

[Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Siegel's.20Lemma)

Co-authored-by: Laura Capuano and Amos Turchet @amosturchet 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: Does this PR depend on the previous one (in the sense that it is branched from the other, or that it needs the other to be mergeable)?

> Does this PR depend on the previous one (in the sense that it is branched from the other, or that it needs the other to be mergeable)?

No, it is independent. The final proof will depend on the two parts.

Really? But the file `Mathlib/NumberTheory/SiegelsLemma.lean` is introduced both in this PR and in #13470 . Assuming #13470 gets merged as it is, you do not want to re-modify lines 1-50, you will want to build upon the outcome of that PR. No?

Yes, I just thought once #13470 is merged I would get a conflict with this and then fix it, or the other way around if this PR is merged first. I am new to this so I do not know what is the best way to proceed. If you think it is better to branch from #13470 I will just get rid of this one and make a new PR.
No, one simply needs to add (as I just did) this dependency in the main message.
Thanks Filippo!

@faenuccio The PR is ready for review. Thank you in advance!
OK, let us know when you want a look again!

> OK, let us know when you want a look again!

So I am done. I got rid of natNorm. It turns out it is not needed. One can prove the inequality of cardinalities using the real number $ \|| A \|| $.

While I was experimenting I wrote the lemma `exists_entry_norm_eq_norm_Matrix` which I think it could be useful in general . If you agree I can make another PR and add the lemma to 'Analysis/Matrix' . Otherwise I will just get rid of it.

It would be great if you guys @faenuccio and @riccardobrasca could take a look now. Thanks in advance!

This looks quite good! My comments are mostly about minor stylistic points.
It wil be great to have Siegel's Lemma in Mathlib for further applications in Diophantine Approximation!

> This looks quite good! My comments are mostly about minor stylistic points. It wil be great to have Siegel's Lemma in Mathlib for further applications in Diophantine Approximation!

Thanks for the feedback and the suggestions, Michael!
I implemented all the changes your suggested

> > This looks quite good! My comments are mostly about minor stylistic points. It wil be great to have Siegel's Lemma in Mathlib for further applications in Diophantine Approximation!
> 
> Thanks for the feedback and the suggestions, Michael! I implemented all the changes your suggested

Can you please hit the "resolve" button on the comment you've addressed?
Sorry for the long line! I was using the web editor, which does not show the 100 character limit.
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9624381232/job/26548034558)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9624381232/job/26548034471)

> LGTM!

Thank you @MichaelStollBayreuth for everything. I learnt a lot from your comments!

Some comments:
1. I have seen that my suggestion to (golf the proof of, and) move the first lemma towards `Analysis.Matrix` has not been taken into account. The golfing is not a big deal (although `fun a \mapsto a` is usually written `(\.)`) but the moving might be important.
2. I think you forgot an "n" in Pigeonhole
3. When you apply a `rw [foo]` to two things you can compact those with `rw [foo] at h1 h2` instead of using two lines.

But thanks for the work!
@faenuccio I had not realized that the first lemma had not been moved before hitting "maintainer merge". Sorry about that! I can make a PR to fix this.

> @faenuccio I had not realized that the first lemma had not been moved before hitting "maintainer merge". Sorry about that! I can make a PR to fix this.

Thanks! Then I would immediately hit `maintainer merge` 😄

In fact, the lemma was just removed [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13487/commits/28788163248f620e21287dd90de968b8707f8b25). @faenuccio Do you still think it should be added to `Analysis.Matrix`?
Good catch, I had not noticed! Then no, I believe it is not needed (I just thought that if it were to appear somewhere, this was not the right place). So all is good @MichaelStollBayreuth , thanks!
LGTM!
LGTM!

```suggestion A.mulVec t = 0 ∧ ‖t‖ ≤ ((n * ‖A‖)^((m : ℝ ) / (n - m))) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion A.mulVec t = 0 ∧ ‖t‖ ≤ ((n * ‖A‖)^((m : ℝ ) / (n - m))) := by ```
I think `Siegel` is a better name for the file (judging on other names in mathlib), but this is not very important.

The guy proved so many very important results that I felt it was not really fair to call `Siegel` a file with only this small (but fundamental) result.

I wonder if we should create a `DiophantineApproximation` folder inside `NumberTheory` and collect this file (which could then be called `Siegel` without shame), the files `DiophantineApproximation` and `WellApproximable` and the folder `Liouville` (I might be missing something) and put them in there.
Yes, a folder is certainly a good idea (and you're right, a file called Siegel in `NumberTheory` is not very good...).
Should I open a discussion on zulip?

I think you can freely create a folder called DiophantineApproximation, but on the other hand I believe that the lemma should not be called Siegel's lemma (the file could, if needed). It would be better if the name "tells" what is going on.
Is it really too painful to use the "standard" norm?
The "normal" norm is a real number?
Yes

I think we will have the good answer only after some trials. In case you end up duplicating a lot of code (especially to prove that this norm is actually integral/positive) then it will be worth it create something, but this will become clearer only after some trial-and-error. You can start without and see how things go.
Let me see if I can avoid it.

I think one can make a lemma that extracts the indices `i` and `j` that realise the sups in the norm and then work with that. It would be something like $\exists i, j :  \|| A \|| = \|| A_{ij}\||$. The RHS is by definition the cast of a `natAbs (A i j)`.

The real question is if you think this is a useful notion for others results (I guess it is?): in that case it is worth to create a new file, write the def and develop a basic API (even just the lemma you already have).
Let me think about it. I'll try a couple of things
We are in the root namespace, right? I guess `Matrix` or something would be better.
I put everything in the `Matrix` namespace.
Can you use `refine ... ?_ ...`, where the `?_` corresponds to `this` here? It would make the proof nicer.
Done!

```suggestion
  simp only [norm_eq_sup_sup_nnnorm]
  obtain ⟨i, hi⟩ := Finset.exists_mem_eq_sup _ univ_nonempty (univ.sup fun j => ‖A · j‖₊)
  obtain ⟨j, hj⟩ := Finset.exists_mem_eq_sup _ univ_nonempty (‖A i ·‖₊)
  exact ⟨i, j, by rw [hi.2, hj.2]⟩
```
and yes, please move this lemma out, to where you suggested to. Than we can revise the whole Siegel part. Thanks!
I think Mathlib style is to use `↦` (\mapsto) instead of `=>` with `fun`?
I see this comment has unfortunately not been taken into account. It is not a great deal, but apart from the golfing I believe this lemma should not stay there but be mobed to `Analysis.Matrix`.

```suggestion
private lemma image_T_subset_S : ∀ v ∈ T, A.mulVec v ∈ S := by
```
There are many unnecessary parentheses. I'll flag some of them, but it is best if you try for yourself which ones are really needed.
Also, you can use notation `A *ᵥ v` for the matrix-vector product.

```suggestion
      fun i ↦ Finset.sum univ fun j : Fin n ↦ A i j * v j := rfl
```

```suggestion
  all_goals
    simp only [mul_neg]
    gcongr ∑ _ : Fin n, ?_ with j _ -- get rid of sums
    rw [← mul_comm (v j)] -- move A i j to the right of the products
    by_cases hsign : 0 ≤ A i j -- we have to distinguish cases: we have now 4 goals
```
I think this is a bit clearer (but I don't think there are clear style preferences on this).

Together wthe the `by_cases` line, this can be simplified a bit:
```lean
    rcases le_total 0 (A i j) with hsign | hsign -- we have to distinguish cases: we have now 4 goals
  · rw [negPart_eq_zero.2 hsign]
    exact mul_nonneg (hv.1 j) hsign
  · rw [negPart_eq_neg.2 hsign]
    simp only [mul_neg, neg_neg]
    exact mul_le_mul_of_nonpos_right (hv.2 j) hsign
  · rw [posPart_eq_self.2  hsign]
    exact mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (hv.2 j) hsign
  · rw [posPart_eq_zero.2 hsign]
    exact mul_nonpos_of_nonneg_of_nonpos (hv.1 j) hsign
```

```suggestion
private lemma card_T_eq : (T).card = (B + 1) ^ n := by
```
Note the spacing in `(B + 1) ^ n`.
(I just noticed the parens around `T` are indeed necessary, probably because `T` is notation.)

```suggestion
variable (hA : A ≠ 0)
```
You can move this down to before `one_le_norm_A_of_ne_zero`; it does not appear to be needed earlier.

```suggestion
private lemma N_le_P_add_one (i : Fin m) : N i ≤ P i + 1 := by
```
The preference is to put universally quantified variables and hypotheses left of the `:`; then one does not need to introduce them at the beginning of the proof.

```suggestion
  calc N i
  _ ≤ 0 := by
    apply Finset.sum_nonpos
    intro j _
    simp only [mul_neg, Left.neg_nonpos_iff]
    exact mul_nonneg (Nat.cast_nonneg B) (negPart_nonneg (A i j))
  _ ≤ P i + 1 := by
    apply le_trans (Finset.sum_nonneg _) (Int.le_add_one (le_refl P i))
    intro j _
    exact mul_nonneg (Nat.cast_nonneg B) (posPart_nonneg (A i j))
```
I think this is the preferred `calc` style.

Alternatively, you could use `trans 0` like this:
```lean
  trans 0
  · apply Finset.sum_nonpos
    intro j _
    simp only [mul_neg, Left.neg_nonpos_iff]
    exact mul_nonneg (Nat.cast_nonneg B) (negPart_nonneg (A i j))
  · apply le_trans (Finset.sum_nonneg _) (Int.le_add_one (le_refl P i))
    intro j _
    exact mul_nonneg (Nat.cast_nonneg B) (posPart_nonneg (A i j))
```

```suggestion
private lemma card_S_eq : (Finset.Icc N P).card = ∏ i : Fin m, (P i - N i + 1) := by
```

```suggestion
  by_contra! h
```

```suggestion
  exact Int.abs_lt_one_iff.1 h
```

```suggestion
local notation3 "P" => fun i : Fin m ↦ ∑ j : Fin n, B * posPart (A i j)
local notation3 "N" => fun i : Fin m ↦ ∑ j : Fin n, B * (- negPart (A i j))
-- S is the box where the image of T goes
local notation3 "S" => Finset.Icc N P
```
There are still extra spaces (before `"P"`, `"N"`, `"S"` and the last `∑`).
Sorry, I missed that. It should be ok now

```suggestion
      · have h := N_le_P_add_one m n A i
```

```suggestion
          simp only [sum_const, card_univ, Fintype.card_fin, nsmul_eq_mul, mul_assoc ↑n ‖A‖ ↑B]
```

```suggestion
        · exact mul_nonneg (mul_nonneg (Nat.cast_nonneg n) (norm_nonneg A)) (Nat.cast_nonneg B)
```

```suggestion
          ← rpow_mul (mul_nonneg (Nat.cast_nonneg n) (norm_nonneg A)), ← Real.rpow_natCast, div_mul_cancel₀]
        exact sub_ne_zero_of_ne (mod_cast hn.ne')
```

```suggestion
        · simpa only [sub_pos, cast_lt] using hn
```
BTW, `Nat.cast_nonneg n` can be written as `n.cast_nonneg` etc. ("dot notation").

```suggestion
theorem exists_ne_zero_int_vec_norm_le (hA_nezero : A ≠ 0) : ∃  t : Fin n → ℤ, t ≠ 0 ∧
```

```suggestion
    A.mulVec t = 0 ∧ ‖t‖ ≤ ((n * ‖A‖) ^ ((m : ℝ) / (n - m))) := by
```

```suggestion
  -- proofs that x - y ≠ 0 and x-y is a solution
  refine ⟨x - y, sub_ne_zero.mpr hneq, by simp only [mulVec_sub, sub_eq_zero, hfeq], ?_⟩
```

```suggestion
  have n_mul_norm_A_pow_e_nonneg : 0 ≤ (n * ‖A‖) ^ e := by positivity
```

```suggestion
  simp only [col_apply, Pi.sub_apply]
```
`simp?` likes to include this even when it is not necessary.

It is still one goal at this point (a conjunction).

BTW, can you use a consistent style for the comments? (e.g., " -- <comment>")

Earlier today, when I updated Mathlib, the proof broke here.
Instead of `this` there used to be `← norm_col` but it gave the error 
`typeclass instance problem is stuck, it is often due to metavariables
  Unique ?m.174974`
I fixed it in that way but I imagine there is a better way.
You can use `← norm_col (ι := Unit)`. The statement of `norm_col` changed in #11536.
Thanks!

```suggestion
  constructor --two goals
```

```suggestion
    A *ᵥ t = 0 ∧ ‖t‖ ≤ (n * ‖A‖) ^ ((m : ℝ) / (n - m)) := by
```

```suggestion
        gcongr
        · exact sub_pos.mpr (mod_cast hn)
        · exact Nat.lt_floor_add_one ((n * ‖A‖) ^ e)
```

```suggestion
        congr 1
        rw [← rpow_mul (mul_nonneg n.cast_nonneg (norm_nonneg A)), ← Real.rpow_natCast, div_mul_cancel₀]
```

```suggestion
        rw [← mul_pow, mul_add, mul_one]
        gcongr
        have H : 1 ≤ (n : ℝ) := mod_cast (hm.trans hn)
        exact one_le_mul_of_one_le_of_one_le H <| one_le_norm_A_of_ne_zero m n A hA
```

```suggestion
      refine Finset.prod_le_prod (fun i _ ↦ ?_) (fun i _ ↦ ?_)
```
I prefer this, but it is a matter of taste.

```suggestion
        simp_rw [h1, ← Finset.sum_add_distrib, ← mul_add, mul_comm ‖A‖, ← Int.cast_add]
        gcongr with j _
        rw [posPart_add_negPart (A i j), Int.cast_abs]
        exact norm_entry_le_entrywise_sup_norm A
```
Trying to manipulate the expressions so that `gcongr` can do more.
